title: House sitting: Aussies ditching rental homes and saving thousands
text:
A growing number of “nomadic” Victorians are saving tens of thousands of dollars on rent and bills each year by becoming full-time house sitters.

The rising cost of buying and renting homes is a significant factor driving people to the lifestyle, with those aged in their 20s and 30s the most prevalent participants, experts say.

Leading platform Mindahome says it’s seen a 10-20 per cent increase in sitters using the site nationwide each year, over the past six years, with “thousands” now on its books.

Tamara, 29, and Jess, 24, who didn’t want their surnames published, have lived in almost a dozen homes in suburbs including Craigieburn, Richmond, Glen Waverley and Ascot Vale since they started sitting full-time in February.

The couple estimates it’ll save $20,000 per year from not having to cover rent or utility bills.

Their stays have ranged from two days to five weeks.

Almost all the homeowners they’ve sat for have had pets, ranging from a pug puppy in a Carlton house through to a 20-year-old cat in their current Elwood digs.

Tamara said they were dissatisfied with their Mentone rental, and facing the prospect of having to “overextend ourselves” financially to find a better one, when they took the plunge.

They sold most of their furniture, signed up to sites including Mindahome, and moved into their first temporary abode soon after.

Their day-to-day belongings have been reduced to five crates and two bags of clothing and food, plus bedding.

Jess said the savings had allowed her to concentrate on her university studies without the distraction of a part-time job.

“We’re meeting really lovely people who’ve said they’d call us again. And we get to eat our way around Melbourne,” she said.

Tamara said they were enjoying the “nomadic” lifestyle, and were lucky to have their parents’ houses on standby as places to crash if sitting jobs fell through.

“It’s very competitive,” she said.

“Initially it’s really hard to get places, but it’s gotten easier (as) homeowners review us.”

The pair said keeping an up-to-date online presence was crucial, as they were contacted by homeowners for most of their sitting jobs, not the other way around.

“People find us — we went through a phase where we were trying to message people, but people who sign up to these websites get 30 messages a day from people wanting to house sit,” Jess said.

When it came to meeting homeowners, Tamara said it was important to treat it “like a job interview”.

During the sit, they tried not leave the home vacant for more than four or five hours and always left the house in the same condition as they found it.

Mindahome co-founder Sue Coombs said there was plenty of demand for house sitters — especially in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland — with 500-900 Aussie homes seeking sitters were listed on the site each day.

This peaked at 1500 during holidays.

Ms Coombs said the vast majority of the jobs involved pet sitting, with homeowners also often wanting their mail collected, their garden cared for and the added security of having someone at their residence.

She said 40 per cent of Mindahome’s sitters were saving for house deposits. Other common candidates were retirees looking for “cheap holidays” and people “road testing” suburbs they were interested in moving to.

TIPS FOR FULL-TIME HOUSE SITTERS

-Ask questions: make sure you know what’s expected of you, and that you have all the information you need to complete and enjoy the sit

-Be professional: treat every position you apply for like a job application

-Travel light: it’s much easier if you’re going from place to place, and most facilities are provided at the homes.

-Have a ‘Plan B’: a place you can stay should there be a gap between sitting jobs

-Provide references or testimonials from past house sitting jobs, and a police check

-Create a good online profile: detail why an owner would want to hire you and include a photo of yourself

-Be flexible with your dates

-Be willing to perform specific tasks requested by the owner, such as gardening, collecting the mail etc

Source: Mindahome’s Sue Coombs
description: Full-time house sitters Tamara and Jess have lived in almost a dozen homes in nine months — and saved tens of thousands of dollars. Here’s how to join the “nomadic” movement.
